content: so this is the barn tile and I've used techniques from the other videos to
create this tile and I'll explain what I did as you can see it's wood it's not
done in the stone texture like the dungeon tiles so you would just paint it
like I did in the boat tutorial just paint it the wood texture instead of the
instead of doing that or spraying the stone texture on it so spray it black
and then paint the wood texture on it as I did in the boat tutorial I've also
used the glue gun here to do a straw and hay texture on the tile and I did that
in the prison tile so I showed how to do that now this Gore is a combination I
just used the glue gun to make the smudges for the gore just gooped it up a
little bit to make the guts and gore and then I painted it with several different
shades of red and then I used the poly acrylic water-based finish to give it
that glassy texture to make it look like it was wet gore so that really added to
the to the to the tile and basically what I did for the loft area was I built
the rectangle tile and then I put these two loft areas attached to the rectangle
tile and I'll try to show that to see that that edge there so there's - this
piece is on this piece so I tried to give it some dimension that this was
higher and you know it's not really that much higher but you can just say when
the player moves to the edge that it's you know it's actually 10 feet in the
air you know so they would and the werewolves destroyed the ladder so there
is no way to get up there unless they tried to climb beside the barn so that's
really it and
now what we did what we you saw we did was interesting was we put a piece of
black poster board on top of the tile so put that on the top and that covers it
up so that when the players they can see the edge they can see the edging they
can see the dimension of the building and walk around it but they can't see
what's in it so you know let the dungeon tile you can
just put the dungeon tiles down as you need them so that's how you reveal but
if you wanted to have some buildings out but you didn't want to show what was
inside the building you could do this easy technique of just putting a piece
of poster board on top of the tile and that completely hides it so that's kind
of a you know a fog of war effect I guess from from a video game it'd be the
same type of thing so what I'm going to do is show you how to do this how to cut
this piece out very easily and we'll do that now
okay so I'm going to make the the fog of war for this tile and basically I have a
piece of poster board here it's just black poster board that's all it is
and what I could do is I can try to trace it but then it won't fit in the
confines of the tile so what I find it easier to do is just get part of the
straight part of the tile or a part of the poster board and just set it on top
and since this is you know just a rectangular room it fits this edge fits
this edge but I need to cut this edge so I'll turn this around and I use my
pointer here to make it easier and now I'm using a pencil because it's easier
to see on the poster board I'll just trace that and cut
okay that doesn't quite fit it's not coming off okay okay so that looks good
so now what I'll do is I need to cut this this edge off so I can see these
two walls so it'll be pretty easy to measure so let's turn around this way so
I can get to it the ruler like that just use my pencil mark across so now I've
got instant fog of war so before they explore this tile I can have this just
this black piece on here or if they look inside I can take it off and they can
see all the horribleness inside another thing you could do is make a roof on it
that just sits on top of it one thing to think about when doing the roof is for
once a little more work but it might make it look a little better when you
make the roof a lot of commercial buildings the roofs are very are very
sharp it's like that's not very good for gameplay because you can't put any
figures on the roof they fall off so if somebody wants to climb on the roof I
would make the slope a lot less angled so that player characters could climb on
the roof and stand on the roof without the without the the miniatures fall
sliding off so that's one thing I recommend if you want to do roofs and I
have done whole buildings for games and I will show those at a later date but
this is a great way to do an individual building tile with with these methods
now I want to show you these templates that I made and these were in case
somebody got smashed through the wall so what I did is if they came out of wall
at a particular point I would put that against the wall and I would show that
they smashed through the wall and then the player player characters could come
through the hole that they smashed through so all I did to make these was I
just took a piece of cardstock you can see it's just very thin and I just took
the glue gun and put some smears on it and then painted it with the wood
texture so it kind of looks like some debris from the smashed wall
hey this was a short and sweet DMS craft bruh the shortest video I've ever done I
hope you enjoyed the techniques I just wanted to show you that kind of thinking
outside the box of the dungeon tile there's just so many things you can do
with these techniques and I also want to show you how I use like cloth on the
table to help make the tiles not slide and also to give the surrounding texture
like I used I used a grass cloth that made it look like the outside so if you
did a dungeon tiles you could put down a black cloth and that'd be great because
then you wouldn't see the table through it'd be like the black areas that
weren't discovered yet so I think that's that's a pretty cool idea so thanks
again for joining me and see you next time with a DMS craft
